What's the best way to paint rustic wood beams?

Here’s a reliable, step-by-step method for painting rustic (rough-sawn or irregular) wood beams so the finish looks good and lasts.

1. Inspect & Repair  
   • Look for loose splinters, deep cracks, rot or insect damage.  
   • Fill shallow cracks with an exterior-grade wood filler; replace severely damaged sections before painting.

2. Clean Thoroughly  
   • Vacuum or broom off loose dust.  
   • Scrub with a stiff nylon brush and a solution of TSP substitute or mild detergent and warm water to remove dirt, cobwebs, grease and soot.  
   • Rinse with clean water and let the beams dry completely (24–48 h is typical).

3. De-Gloss & Smooth Selectively  
   • Rustic beams generally have ridges and saw marks you want to keep. Sand only where there are high splinters or hardened dirt, using 80- to 120-grit paper.  
   • Wipe away sanding dust with a damp microfiber cloth.

4. Mask Surroundings  
   • Use painter’s tape and plastic sheeting to protect ceilings, walls and floors.  
   • Lay drop cloths beneath the work area.

5. Prime for Adhesion & Stain Blocking  
   • Choose a high-bond, stain-blocking primer (oil-based or a bonding acrylic/urethane hybrid). These seal old tannins and pitch that could bleed through paint.  
   • Apply with a 2½–3 in. stiff-bristle brush, working the primer into grooves, knots and end grain.  
   • Allow the recommended dry time (often 2–4 h for an acrylic, 6–8 h for an oil primer).

6. Caulk Gaps (Optional)  
   • If you want a tighter, more finished look, caulk between the beam and ceiling/wall joint using a paintable, elastomeric sealant after primer is dry.

7. Paint  
   • Paint Type: A high-quality 100 % acrylic latex offers durability and low odor indoors; for historic or chalky matte looks, consider mineral or chalk paint, but seal afterward with a clear matte polyurethane if you need scrub resistance.  
   • Sheen: Satin hides surface variations better than semi-gloss yet still wipes clean.  
   • Application: Use the same stiff-bristle brush or a 4-in. “jumbo” brush. Work paint into recesses first, then drag along the grain to even out brush marks. Two thin coats are better than one thick coat; allow proper dry time between coats (usually 2–4 h).

8. Optional Topcoat  
   • For damp locations or heavy traffic areas, finish with a clear, water-based polyurethane or acrylic urethane in matte or satin. Let the paint cure at least 24 h before top-coating.

9. Cleanup & Curing  
   • Remove tape while paint is still slightly tacky to avoid cracking the paint line.  
   • Cure time before heavy use or cleaning: roughly 7 days for most latex paints.

Helpful Product Picks at Zava  
   • Zava Pro-Bond Interior/Exterior Primer-Sealer (oil or acrylic versions)  
   • Z-Flex 100 % Acrylic Latex Paint, Satin, custom color match available  
   • Zava ‘Rustic-Edge’ 3-in. Synthetic Bristle Brush (holds up on rough wood)  
   • Heavy-Duty Drop Cloth (reusable canvas)  
   • Non-Slip Painter’s Staging Planks if the beams are overhead

Pro Tips  
   • Test color and adhesion on the back side of one beam first.  
   • Maintain good ventilation—open windows or run a box fan—especially if you use an oil primer.  
   • A headlamp helps you see missed spots in the beam grooves.

If you need specific color advice, quantities, or safety gear suggestions, just let me know. Happy painting from all of us at Zava!

What's the best way to paint over mildew-resistant paint?

Here’s a reliable, paint-manufacturer-approved method that contractors use when they have to repaint walls or trim that were previously coated with a mildew-resistant finish. The goal is to (a) remove any actual mildew, (b) give the new paint something to “bite” into, and (c) keep the new coat from peeling or flashing.

——————————————————
Tools & materials
• Safety glasses, N95 (or better) mask, gloves  
• Drop cloths / painter’s tape  
• Soft scrub brush or Scotch-Brite pad  
• Mildew remover (diluted household bleach* or a commercial fungicidal wash)  
• TSP-substitute cleaner or a mild degreasing soap  
• 120- to 150-grit sanding sponge or pole sander  
• Bonding or stain-blocking primer (latex or alkyd; look for “high-adhesion” and “mildew-resistant” on the label)  
• Quality acrylic-latex topcoat—standard or mildew-resistant formula  
• ¼"–⅜" nap roller (walls) or a smooth-finish microfiber roller (trim)  
• Angled sash brush

*If you use bleach, OSHA recommends a 3:1 water-to-bleach ratio. Never mix bleach with ammonia or other cleaners.

——————————————————
Step-by-step

1. Kill and remove any active mildew  
   • Mix your bleach solution or use a premixed fungicidal wash.  
   • Wet the surface, scrub lightly, then let the solution sit for 10–15 min.  
   • Rinse with clean water and let the area dry completely (overnight is ideal).

2. Wash the paint film  
   • Even if it looks clean, mildew-resistant coatings accumulate soap scum, cooking oils or cigarette residue that can interfere with adhesion.  
   • Use a TSP substitute or mild detergent, rinse, and allow to dry.

3. Scuff-sand / degloss  
   • Buff the entire painted surface with 120- or 150-grit. You’re not trying to remove the coating—just dull the sheen so the primer keys in.  
   • Wipe off dust with a barely damp cloth or tack cloth.

4. Spot-patch if needed  
   • Fill nail holes or small dents with a lightweight spackle, sand smooth, and dust off.

5. Prime  
   • A high-adhesion acrylic or alkyd bonding primer is the insurance policy here. Two advantages:  
       – Locks down any residual staining.  
       – Gives the new finish coat the “tooth” it needs, especially over glossy mildew-proof paints.  
   • Follow the can’s dry-time; many primers can be top-coated in an hour, but alkyds may need 4–6 hrs.

6. Finish coat(s)  
   • Apply one or two coats of a quality 100 % acrylic paint. If the room is moisture-prone (bath, laundry, coastal porch), choose a mildew-resistant version again for added protection.  
   • Maintain the “wet edge” as you roll, and back-roll in sections to avoid lap marks.  
   • Respect the recoat window—usually 2–4 hrs for latex.

7. Cure & care  
   • Full cure for latex is about 7 days. During that time, avoid scrubbing the walls.  
   • Keep the space ventilated to reduce future mildew growth: run exhaust fans, keep humidity below ~60 %.

——————————————————
Extra tips

• If the existing paint is oil-based (rare for new mildew-resistant paints but possible in older homes), you’ll still use the same cleaning and sanding steps, but definitely prime with a bonding primer rated for “oil-to-latex” transitions.  
• Paint applied before 1978 can contain lead. If you suspect that, use an EPA-recognized test or consult a certified lead-safe contractor before sanding.  
• For ceilings in shower areas, a stain-blocking primer tinted to your top-coat color helps hide water spots and reduces the chance of “flashing” (uneven sheen).

——————————————————
Need supplies?

Zava stocks:
• ZavaPro Mold-Kill Cleaner (ready-to-use fungicidal wash)  
• KrudKutter TSP-Free Surface Prep  
• Zinsser® Bulls Eye 1-2-3 Plus (high-adhesion, mildew-resistant)  
• Benjamin Moore® Aura Bath & Spa (matte mildew-resistant)  
• Purdy® Nylox Glide 2½" brush and Colossus ⅜" rollers  

Let me know if you’d like help matching colors, figuring coverage, or choosing a different product line—happy to help!

What's the best way to paint built-in bookshelves?

Painting built-in bookcases is mostly about careful prep and patience between coats. Below is a reliable “pro” method that works for both new, unfinished cabinets and older shelves that already have paint or clear finish on them.

1. Empty, label and remove what you can  
   • Take out all books and décor.  
   • If shelves are adjustable, remove and label them so they go back in the same positions.

2. Mask and protect adjacent surfaces  
   • Lay down drop cloths.  
   • Use painter’s tape where shelves meet the wall, ceiling and floor.  
   • If you have inset lighting, mask the fixtures or remove the trims.

3. Clean thoroughly  
   • Deglossers or a mild TSP substitute will cut grease and hand oils that stop paint from bonding.  
   • Rinse with clean water and let dry.

4. Lightly sand (even on “factory-smooth” pieces)  
   • 120- to 150-grit sanding sponges are ideal for flats and profiles.  
   • Vacuum and tack-cloth away every trace of dust—little nibs telegraph through the finish.

5. Fill, caulk and spot-prime  
   • Fill nail holes with wood putty and sand flush.  
   • Run paintable caulk along the back edge where the shelf meets the wall for a built-in look.  
   • If you hit bare wood or bare MDF, spot-prime those areas; raw MDF in particular will swell without primer.

6. Prime the whole unit if:  
   • You’re covering bare wood, MDF or plywood.  
   • The old finish is glossy oil or lacquer.  
   • You’re changing from dark to light.  
   Recommended primers from our store: Zinsser BIN shellac (best stain-blocking, quick dry) or Zinsser 1-2-3 water-based (low odor, sands nicely).

7. Sand the primer lightly (220-grit) and vacuum again.  
   • This “denibs” the surface and makes the topcoat flow better.

8. Choose the right paint  
   • Water-based acrylic enamel or “cabinet & trim” paints are durable and level out well (Behr Scuff Defense, Benjamin Moore Advance, Sherwin-Williams Emerald Urethane, etc.).  
   • Satin or semi-gloss is traditional for wipe-ability; matte shows fewer brush marks but isn’t as washable.

9. Apply the finish coat(s)  
   • Cut in corners and profiles first with a 2″ angled sash brush.  
   • Immediately roll each flat section with a 4″ microfiber or foam roller; light pressure prevents orange-peel.  
   • “Tip off” final strokes in the direction of the wood grain for a sprayed look.  
   • Two thin coats beat one thick coat—plan on 2–3 hours between coats (or per the can) and a 24-hour gentle cure before heavy use.

10. Reassemble and let cure fully  
    • Once the paint is dry to the touch, reinstall adjustable shelves.  
    • Wait at least 7 days before sliding heavy hard-cover books into place; paint needs that time to reach full hardness.

Quick tips & add-ons:  
• Use a mini paint pail with a magnet to hold your brush—reduces drips when working inside deep cubbies.  
• If your shelves are laminate, swap the primer for a bonding primer (Stix or Bulls-Eye 1-2-3 MAX).  
• A small foam detail roller or a 1½″ trim brush gets into the shelf lip without loading on excess paint.  
• Keep a damp rag in your pocket to catch any wet paint that strays onto the wall before it skins over.

Need product links, square footage estimates, or color-matching? Let me know your shelf dimensions and current finish, and I’ll help you build a shopping list.

How do I paint a brick wall interior?

Here’s a straightforward, step-by-step guide to painting an interior brick wall so the finish looks crisp, durable and professional. Feel free to adjust the steps to suit your project or available tools.

1. Inspect and repair the brickwork
   • Look for cracks, crumbling mortar, efflorescence (white powder) or mildew.  
   • Patch any holes or cracks with interior-grade mortar repair or acrylic caulk. Allow repairs to cure fully (check product label; often 24 h).  
   • If the brick is damp, trace and fix the source first—paint will not adhere properly to moisture-laden masonry.

2. Clean thoroughly
   • Vacuum or dry-brush off loose dust and grit.  
   • Wash the surface with warm water, mild detergent and a stiff nylon brush. For greasy soot (e.g., near a fireplace) add TSP substitute or degreaser.  
   • Rinse well and let the wall dry at least 24 h; brick is porous and must be completely dry before priming.

3. Mask and protect surroundings
   • Cover floors with drop cloths; tape off adjacent walls, trim, outlets and fixtures with painter’s tape.  
   • If the brick meets a finished floor, run a bead of painter’s caulk to seal gaps and stop paint bleed.

4. Choose the right primer
   • Use a high-quality masonry or multi-surface bonding primer.  
   • If stain or soot is present, a stain-blocking primer (acrylic or shellac) prevents bleed-through.  
   • For very porous, raw brick, consider a block-filler primer to even out the surface and reduce paint consumption.

5. Prime the wall
   • Stir the primer well; pour into a paint tray.  
   • Cut in edges and mortar lines with a 2–2½ in (50–65 mm) synthetic brush.  
   • Roll the larger faces with a ½–¾ in (12–19 mm) nap roller or a smaller “hot dog” roller for tight spots.  
   • Work the primer into crevices; back-brush while wet if necessary.  
   • Allow to dry as directed (usually 1–4 h for acrylic primers).

6. Select a paint formulated for masonry
   • Interior 100 % acrylic latex paint is the most common.  
   • Choose sheen:  
       – Flat or matte hides surface irregularities.  
       – Eggshell or satin is more scrubbable for high-traffic areas.  
   • If near a fireplace opening, use a high-heat paint within the firebox and regular latex on the facing (check temperature limits on the can).  
   • Plan on two coats for uniform coverage.

7. Apply the paint
   • Stir well; do not thin unless product label allows.  
   • Cut in first, then roll large areas—same tools as for primer.  
   • Maintain a wet edge and work the paint into mortar joints.  
   • Wait the recommended recoat time (usually 2–4 h) before the second coat.  
   • A third coat may be necessary on very dark or rough brick.

8. Final touches
   • Remove painter’s tape while the last coat is still slightly tacky to reduce peeling.  
   • Touch up any missed mortar joints with a small brush.  
   • Let the paint cure (about 7 days for latex) before aggressive scrubbing or hanging décor.

Helpful extras available at Zava
   • Zava-Prime Masonry Sealer/Primer (1 gal, covers ~250 sq ft on rough brick)  
   • Zava 100 % Acrylic Interior Wall & Trim Paint, Eggshell finish  
   • ¾ in shed-resistant roller covers, stiff nylon brick brush, low-tack painter’s tape  
   • Ready-to-use TSP-Free Wall Cleaner and Safety Kit (gloves, goggles, mask)  

Tip: Keep a small labeled jar of touch-up paint sealed tightly. Interior brick can chip over time, and a quick dab restores the finish.

That’s it! With proper prep, brick accepts paint beautifully and the result will last for years. If you have any other questions—about color selection, tools or drying times—just let me know. Happy painting from Zava!

How do I paint a room with pets?

Here’s a step-by-step guide to painting a room while keeping dogs, cats, birds or other household pets safe and stress-free.

1. Choose the right paint  
   • Look for low- or zero-VOC (volatile organic compound) interior paint. It reduces fumes that can irritate pets’ respiratory systems.  
   • Opt for an eggshell or satin finish for walls; they’re easier to clean if muddy paws or wet noses touch them later.  
   • Speak with a Zava paint specialist if you need help matching colors or picking a pet-friendly brand.

2. Gather supplies up front  
   • Paint, primer (if needed)  
   • Rollers, brushes, extension pole  
   • Painter’s tape, drop cloths or plastic sheeting  
   • Paint tray liners, stirring sticks  
   • Disposable gloves and a respirator or high-quality mask for you  
   • A door sweep, baby gate or temporary pet barrier

3. Create a safe, separate zone for pets  
   • Select a room farthest from the area you’ll paint.  
   • Move their food, water, bedding and toys there.  
   • Close doors and use a baby gate if needed. Birds are especially sensitive to fumes—move their cage to a different floor if possible.

4. Prep the room quickly and thoroughly  
   • Remove or cover furniture with plastic sheeting.  
   • Fill nail holes and sand lightly—wipe dust with a damp cloth.  
   • Tape off trim, outlets and switches.  
   • Lay down drop cloths to keep fur off fresh paint and prevent slips.

5. Ventilation is critical  
   • Open windows and use fans to exhaust air outward. Place one fan facing out of a window and another drawing fresh air in.  
   • Close HVAC vents in that room so fumes don’t circulate through the ductwork.

6. Paint efficiently  
   • “Cut in” edges with a brush first, then roll the larger areas.  
   • Work from top (ceiling line) down to baseboards, and paint one wall at a time to keep a wet edge.  
   • Keep paint lids closed when not in use to limit odor.

7. Monitor dry-time & fumes before reintroducing pets  
   • Most low-VOC paints are dry to the touch in 1–2 hours and ready for a second coat in 4–6, but they can off-gas for up to 24–48 hours.  
   • Wait until paint is fully dry and the smell has dissipated before letting pets back in—overnight is a good rule of thumb.  
   • If weather allows, continue ventilating for an extra day.

8. Post-paint cleanup  
   • Seal brushes and rollers in plastic between coats or wash them promptly with mild soap and warm water if using water-based paint.  
   • Remove painter’s tape at a 45° angle while paint is slightly tacky to avoid peeling.  
   • Store leftover paint in an airtight can, clearly labeled. Keep it on a high shelf or locked cabinet away from curious animals.

9. Quick tips for specific animals  
   • Dogs/Cats: Provide chew toys or puzzle feeders in their safe room to reduce anxiety from unfamiliar noises.  
   • Birds: Even low-VOC paints can produce particulates that irritate their lungs; relocating them to a friend’s house is ideal.  
   • Small mammals (rabbits, hamsters): Cover their enclosures with breathable cloth and place an air purifier nearby if relocation isn’t possible.

10. What to watch for  
    • If a pet accidentally steps in wet paint, rinse paws with lukewarm water and mild dish soap—most latex paints are water-based and non-toxic in small amounts, but ingestion can cause mild digestive upset. Contact a vet if you’re unsure.  
    • For oil-based or specialty paints, keep the emergency vet’s number handy; solvents can be harmful if ingested or inhaled.

Need supplies or color samples? Stop by Zava and we’ll mix low-VOC paint on site and help you choose the right brushes, drop cloths and safety gear—so both you and your pets stay comfortable while you transform your space. Happy painting!

What's the most durable finish for wood floors?

When customers ask us for “the toughest finish money can buy,” the answer depends on whether the floor is:

A. Already pre-finished at the factory, or  
B. Being finished (or refinished) on-site.

Below is a quick durability “ladder” plus the pros, cons and what’s realistic for a DIY job.

──────────────────────────
1. Factory-applied, UV-cured ALUMINUM-OXIDE finish
──────────────────────────
• Durability: Outstanding. Tiny aluminum-oxide particles are embedded in multiple UV-cured coats, giving wear resistance that can exceed 25-year residential warranties.  
• Repairability: Spot repairs are difficult; boards usually need to be replaced if you get through the wear layer.  
• DIY suitability: Not a DIY process (done by the manufacturer), but worth knowing because pre-finished planks with this coating will outlast any site-applied film.  
• Brands we stock/see often: Bruce Dura-Luster Plus, Mohawk TecWood with ArmorMax, Mannington with ScratchResist.

──────────────────────────
2. Acid-cured “Swedish” CONVERSION VARNISH
──────────────────────────
• Durability: Hard, chemically resistant, almost as tough as aluminum-oxide.  
• Drawbacks: Very high VOCs (strong odor), flammable fumes, specialized respirators required, tricky pot-life (must be used within a few hours of mixing). For that reason it’s almost always applied by a pro.  
• DIY suitability: Generally not recommended unless you have pro experience and protective gear.

──────────────────────────
3. Moisture-cured or Two-component (2K) POLYURETHANE
──────────────────────────
• Durability: Next tier down but still excellent for heavy traffic. 2-component water-borne systems (e.g., Bona Traffic HD, Loba 2K Supra) reach 90-95 % of the abrasion resistance of Swedish finishes, with far lower odor and easier clean-up.  
• Cure time: Walkable in 24 h; full cure in 3–7 days.  
• DIY suitability: Very doable for careful DIYers—just mix the hardener exactly as directed and maintain good ventilation.

──────────────────────────
4. Traditional oil-based POLYURETHANE
──────────────────────────
• Durability: Good. Slightly softer than the options above but still the “workhorse” finish in North America. Adds a warm amber tone that many people like.  
• Cure time: Tack-free in 8–12 h; full cure 2–3 weeks.  
• DIY suitability: Straightforward; longest open time, which gives beginners a little forgiveness.

──────────────────────────
5. Single-component WATER-BORNE POLYURETHANE
──────────────────────────
• Durability: Fair to good. Lower VOC and faster drying (2–4 h between coats), but because it doesn’t have a separate hardener it tops out a bit softer.  
• Best use: Light-to-medium traffic rooms or when you want minimal color change.

──────────────────────────
6. Penetrating oils, waxes, shellac, etc.
──────────────────────────
• Durability: Lowest surface abrasion resistance, though they are easy to spot-repair. Historically popular but not what you’d choose primarily for longevity.

So, “most durable” in practical terms:

• Buying new flooring: Choose boards with a factory UV-cured aluminum-oxide topcoat.  
• Site-finishing and willing to pay a pro: Acid-cured conversion varnish.  
• High-end DIY or pro with lower fumes: Two-component water-borne polyurethane (Bona Traffic HD, Loba 2K, Pall-X Power, etc.).  
• Budget-friendly DIY that still lasts: Traditional oil-based polyurethane (Minwax Super Fast-Drying Poly, Varathane Professional, Zava-brand ProShield Oil Poly).

Application tips for long life (regardless of product):

1. Sand to at least 100–120 grit and vacuum thoroughly.  
2. Follow the manufacturer’s recommended number of coats—usually three for polys (one sealer + two build coats).  
3. Maintain film thickness: don’t “stretch” a gallon; aim for about 500 ft² per gallon per coat for water-borne, 350–400 ft² for oil-based.  
4. Respect cure times before putting rugs or furniture back.  
5. Add felt pads and a good entry mat system to preserve your hard work.

Need product sheets or applicators? Feel free to let us know the square footage you’re tackling and we can price out specific kits from our stock.

How do I paint terra cotta pots?

Painting terracotta pots is easy, but a few extra prep-steps will make the finish brighter, longer-lasting and more water-resistant. Here’s a complete process that works for both indoor decor pieces and outdoor planters.

-------------------------------------------------
1. Gather your materials
• Mild dish soap and a scrub brush  
• Clean rags or paper towels  
• 220-grit sandpaper (optional, for very rough pots)  
• Sealer for porous clay (water-based masonry/terracotta sealer or an “all-purpose” clear craft sealer)  
• Multi-surface primer (or white acrylic/latex paint that says “primer/paint in one”)  
• Paint: acrylic craft paint, outdoor patio paint, chalk paint, or spray paint formulated for clay/ceramic  
• Good-quality synthetic brushes or foam brushes; or aerosol cans if you prefer spraying  
• Clear topcoat: acrylic sealer, outdoor polyurethane, or clear spray enamel (matte, satin or gloss)  
• Drop cloth, stir sticks, disposable gloves

Everything on the list is usually stocked in the paint and craft aisles at Zava.

-------------------------------------------------
2. Clean and dry the pot
• Scrub off clay dust and any mineral deposits with warm soapy water.  
• Rinse well; let the pot air-dry at least overnight. Terracotta must be bone-dry or moisture will push through later and cause peeling or white haze.

-------------------------------------------------
3. (Optional) Light sanding
If the surface is rough, knock it down with 220-grit sandpaper and wipe off the dust. A smoother pot needs less paint and gives crisper lines for taped or stenciled designs.

-------------------------------------------------
4. Seal the interior (and, if you like, the exterior)
Why: Terracotta is extremely porous, so it “breathes” and wicks water. Sealing:  
• Inside: Brush or spray one to two thin coats of water-based masonry/terracotta sealer. Let it soak in and dry per label (usually 1-2 h between coats, 24 h cure).  
• Rim/Top inch of the inside: Also seal this area—water often evaporates here and can push through exterior paint.  
• Optional outside seal: Adds longevity, especially for outdoor use, but you can rely on primer alone if you prefer a weathered look.

-------------------------------------------------
5. Prime the exterior
• Apply one thin, even coat of multi-surface primer/paint.  
• Let it dry (30 min to 1 h for most primers).  
• A second coat fills any last pinholes and gives a bright, level surface so colors pop.

-------------------------------------------------
6. Paint your design
Hand-painting: Use regular acrylic craft paint, outdoor patio paint or chalk paint.  
Spray-painting: Use light passes, 8–12 in away, rotating the pot.  
• Work in thin coats; heavy coats can drip or trap air.  
• Dry time: 20–30 min between coats; full coverage usually takes 2–3 coats.  
• For stripes, blocks or patterns, let each color dry, then use painter’s tape or stencils.

-------------------------------------------------
7. Clear-coat for protection
When the artwork is fully dry, seal with a clear finish:  
• Indoor pieces: two light coats of water-based acrylic sealer or matte/satin polyurethane.  
• Outdoor pieces: use an exterior-rated polyurethane, marine spar urethane, or a UV-resistant spray enamel.  
Hold the can 8–10 in away; rotate the pot for even coverage. Let each coat dry per label (usually 1–2 h) and cure 24–48 h before planting.

-------------------------------------------------
8. Planting & care tips
• Add a coffee filter or pottery shard over the drain hole so soil doesn’t clog it.  
• Water normally; sealed/painted pots dry out a bit slower than raw terracotta, so check moisture before watering.  
• If you ever need to clean the outside, wipe gently with a damp cloth—avoid harsh scrubbing pads.

-------------------------------------------------
Quick reference timing
Day 1: Wash pot → Dry overnight  
Day 2: Seal interior (and exterior if desired) → Dry 24 h  
Day 3: Prime → Paint (allow drying)  
Day 4: Clear coat → Cure 24–48 h  
Day 5–6: Pot your plant and enjoy!

That’s it—your terracotta pot should now sport a vibrant, durable finish. If you need specific materials, just let me know and I can point you to the exact aisle or brand names we carry at Zava. Happy painting!

What's the best paint for garage floors?

The “best” coating depends on how you use the garage (occasional parking vs. home workshop), how much prep you’re willing to do, and what you want to spend. Below is a quick hierarchy—from most durable to most economical—along with the key differences, pros/cons, and a few products you can find at Zava.

1. Two-Part 100 % Solids Epoxy Kits  
   • Durability: Commercial-grade—stands up to hot-tire pickup, heavy jacks, and most chemicals.  
   • Finish: High-build, glossy, 8–12 mil dry film. Accepts vinyl chips for texture.  
   • Cure time: Light foot traffic 12-18 h, vehicles 48-72 h.  
   • Prep: Requires thorough concrete cleaning, acid etch or grind, plus a moisture test.  
   • Coverage: ~160–200 sq ft per gallon.  
   • Cost: $1.50–$2.50 / sq ft installed (DIY kit).  
   • Zava examples: Rust-Oleum Professional 100 % Solids Epoxy Kit, Quikrete 100 % Solids Epoxy Garage Coating.

2. Polyurea / Polyaspartic Coatings  
   • Durability: Similar to or slightly better than 100 % solids epoxy; superior UV resistance (won’t amber).  
   • Finish: Very high-gloss; thinner film (4–6 mil) unless multiple coats are applied.  
   • Cure time: Walkable in 2–4 h, vehicles in 24 h—fastest turnaround.  
   • Prep: Same as epoxy (etch or diamond-grind).  
   • Coverage: ~175–225 sq ft per gallon.  
   • Cost: $2.50–$3.50 / sq ft.  
   • Zava examples: Valspar Polyurea Garage Floor System, Rust-Oleum RockSolid Polycuramine (polyurea blend).

3. 1-Part “Epoxy-Acrylic” Concrete Paint  
   • Durability: Better than standard latex paint but less than two-part coatings; moderate resistance to hot-tire pickup.  
   • Finish: Satin or semi-gloss; film build 2–4 mil.  
   • Cure time: Foot traffic 24 h, vehicles 5–7 days.  
   • Prep: Clean and etch; no mixing catalyst required.  
   • Coverage: 300–400 sq ft per gallon.  
   • Cost: $0.40–$0.60 / sq ft.  
   • Zava examples: Behr Premium 1-Part Epoxy, Valspar Garage Floor Epoxy-Acrylic.

4. Standard Latex Concrete Floor Paint  
   • Durability: Adequate for light foot traffic and lawn-equipment storage; prone to hot-tire lift.  
   • Finish: Low-sheen to satin.  
   • Prep: Simple degrease and rinse.  
   • Cost: $0.25–$0.35 / sq ft.  
   • Good for: Budget rentals, quick color change.

Choosing Tips

• Moisture test first: Tape a 2 × 2 ft plastic sheet to the slab for 24 h. If condensation forms, stick with breathable latex paint or install a vapor barrier first.  
• Surface profile matters: A diamond grinder or acid etch (muriatic or citric) opens the pores so coatings anchor well.  
• Temperature/​humidity: Two-part epoxies prefer 60–85 °F and <80 % RH. Polyurea tolerates wider ranges but still avoid direct sunlight during application.  
• Safety: Wear a respirator while etching or mixing catalysts.  
• Add traction: Broadcast vinyl chips or silica while the coating is wet; top-coat with clear if you want extra depth and chemical resistance.

Quick “Which One Should I Get?”  
• Daily mechanic work, welding, or heavy duty: 100 % solids epoxy (add a urethane clear coat for UV/chemical protection).  
• Want it done this weekend and park Monday: Polyurea/polyaspartic.  
• Weekend DIY’er, moderate traffic, tight budget: 1-part epoxy-acrylic.  
• Just need gray color and dust control: Standard latex concrete paint.

What can I use for painting small areas?

For painting small or detailed areas you have several good options, depending on the surface texture and the finish you need:

1. Artist/Detail Brushes  
   • Sizes 0–10 (round or flat) are ideal for corners, trim, furniture edges and tight carvings.  
   • Choose synthetic bristles for water-based paints and natural-bristle or a synthet ic–natural blend for oil-based paints or varnishes.

2. Angled Sash Brush (½"–1")  
   • The angled tips help “cut in” around window frames, skirting boards and switch plates.  
   • Holds more paint than an artist brush, so it speeds up linear runs such as narrow moldings.

3. Foam Brushes (1"–3")  
   • Inexpensive and disposable—great for touch-ups, stain, polyurethane or when you don’t want brush marks.  
   • Not suitable for rough surfaces or heavy, repeated use.

4. Mini (4" or 6") Foam Rollers  
   • Best for flat, smooth panels—cabinet doors, shelves or radiator covers.  
   • Produce an even, lint-free finish without brush strokes.

5. Touch-Up Pens/Bottle Applicators  
   • Pre-filled or refillable units let you dab or draw thin lines—handy for repairing chips on walls, appliances or woodwork.

6. Aerosol Spray Paint  
   • Works for very small parts, furniture hardware, vents or lattice.  
   • Gives a uniform coat on intricate shapes—just mask off surrounding areas and spray in thin passes.

Tips for best results  
• Prep the surface (clean, sand lightly, remove dust).  
• Use painter’s tape to mask borders.  
• Apply thin coats; multiple light coats beat one heavy one and reduce drips.  
• Keep a damp cloth or baby wipe nearby for quick clean-ups on water-based paint.  
• For water-based paints, rinse brushes promptly in warm water; for oils, use mineral spirits.
